question: Question 5-07/19/2004 INELASTIC SCATTERING is the process by which a neutron collides with a nucleus and ...

answers.answer: a. is absorbed, with the nucleus emitting a gamma ray.
answers.feedback: Incorrect. REF: Burn, R., Introduction to Nuclear Reactor Operations, © 1988, §

answers.answer: b. recoils with the same kinetic energy it had prior to the collision.
answers.feedback: Incorrect. REF: Burn, R., Introduction to Nuclear Reactor Operations, © 1988, §

answers.answer: c. recoils with a lower kinetic energy than it had prior to the collision with the nucleus emitting a gamma ray.
answers.feedback: Correct

answers.answer: d. recoils with a higher kinetic energy than it had prior to the collision with the nucleus emitting a gamma ray.
answers.feedback: Incorrect. REF: Burn, R., Introduction to Nuclear Reactor Operations, © 1988, §

question: Question 7-07/19/2004 Which ONE of the following is the correct reason that delayed neutrons enhance control of the reactor?

answers.answer: a. There are more delayed neutrons than prompt neutrons.
answers.feedback: Incorrect. REF: Burn, R., Introduction to Nuclear Reactor Operations, © 1988, §

answers.answer: b. Delayed neutrons take longer to reach thermal equilibrium.
answers.feedback: Incorrect. REF: Burn, R., Introduction to Nuclear Reactor Operations, © 1988, §

answers.answer: c. Delayed neutrons increase the average neutron generation time.
answers.feedback: Correct

answers.answer: d. Delayed neutrons are born at higher energies than prompt neutrons and therefore have a greater effect.
answers.feedback: Incorrect. REF: Burn, R., Introduction to Nuclear Reactor Operations, © 1988, §

question: Question 8-07/19/2004 The PRIMARY reason that a neutron source is installed in the reactor is to ...

answers.answer: a. allow for testing and irradiation of experiments when the core is shutdown.
answers.feedback: Incorrect. REF: Burn, R., Introduction to Nuclear Reactor Operations, © 1988, §

answers.answer: b. supply the neutrons required to start the chain reaction for reactor startups.
answers.feedback: Incorrect. REF: Burn, R., Introduction to Nuclear Reactor Operations, © 1988, §

answers.answer: c. provide a neutron level high enough to be monitored for a controlled reactor startup.
answers.feedback: Correct

answers.answer: d. increase the excess reactivity of the reactor which reduces the frequency for refueling.
answers.feedback: Incorrect. REF: Burn, R., Introduction to Nuclear Reactor Operations, © 1988, §

question: Question 15-07/19/2004 Two critical reactors at low power are identical except that Reactor 1 has a beta fraction of 0.0072 and Reactor 2 has a beta fraction of 0.0060. An equal amount of positive reactivity is inserted into both reactors. Which ONE of the following will be the response of Reactor 2 compared to Reactor 1?

answers.answer: a. The resulting power level will be lower.
answers.feedback: Incorrect. REF: Equation Sheet.

answers.answer: b. The resulting power level will be higher.
answers.feedback: Incorrect. REF: Equation Sheet.

answers.answer: c. The resulting period will be longer.
answers.feedback: Incorrect. REF: Equation Sheet.

answers.answer: d. The resulting period will be shorter.
answers.feedback: Correct

question: Question 16-07/19/2004 Most text books list β for a U^235 fueled reactor as 0.65% delta k/k. However, your SAR lists β_eff as being 0.7% delta k/k. Why is β_eff larger than β?

answers.answer: a. Delayed neutrons are born at higher energies than prompt neutrons resulting in a greater worth for these neutrons.
answers.feedback: Incorrect. REF: Burn, R., Introduction to Nuclear Reactor Operations, © 1988, §

answers.answer: b. Delayed neutrons are born at lower energies than prompt neutrons resulting in a less loss due to leakage for these neutrons.
answers.feedback: Correct

answers.answer: c. the fuel includes U^238 which has a relatively large β for fast fission.
answers.feedback: Incorrect. REF: Burn, R., Introduction to Nuclear Reactor Operations, © 1988, §

answers.answer: d. some U^238 in the core becomes Pu^239 (by neutron absorption) which has a larger β for fission.
answers.feedback: Incorrect. REF: Burn, R., Introduction to Nuclear Reactor Operations, © 1988, §

question: Question 18-07/19/2004 About two minutes following a reactor scram, period has stabilized, and is decreasing at a CONSTANT rate. If reactor power is 10-5% full power what will the power be in three minutes.

answers.feedback: Correct

answers.answer: b. decreases as neutron energy increases

answers.answer: c. increases as target nucleus mass increases
answers.feedback: Incorrect. REF: Burn, R., Introduction to Nuclear Reactor Operations, © 1988, §

answers.answer: d. decreases as target nucleus mass increases
answers.feedback: Incorrect. REF: Burn, R., Introduction to Nuclear Reactor Operations, © 1988, §
